rounds.response:
It’s the very first turn, so there’s no offer from Player 0 yet.  
Before I speak or propose anything, I first estimate the value I and my opponent place on each good. The opponent most likely values goods the same way the rules (or a Catan-style economy) do, so:

- Wheat = 5  
- Wood = 12  
- Sheep = 13  
- Brick = 28  
- Ore = 34  

Right now my inventory has a total value of

18·5 + 10·12 + 25·13 + 8·28 + 5·34  
= 90 + 120 + 325 + 224 + 170  
= 929 points.

I look for the biggest mis-match between how I value a good and the standard value. Brick (28 pts) and Ore (34 pts) are my two highest-valued items, while Wheat (5 pts) is easily my lowest.  
Thus, I’d like to trade away Wheat and/or some Sheep (13) to acquire more Brick and Ore.

The most straightforward deal is 3-for-1: three of a low-value good for one of a high-value good. Single-card offers reduce hand-size and are easy for the opponent to evaluate.  
I’ll make the first move with a simple 3 Sheep for 1 Brick proposal, since 3×13 = 39 is slightly more than 28 for Brick, so it looks fair on raw points, but I’m happy to adjust after hearing Player 0’s response.

[Offer: 3 Sheep -> 1 Brick]

rounds.response:
I’m starting to look at the values I have:

- Wheat (18) – 5 pts each  
- Wood (10) – 12 pts each  
- Sheep (25) – 13 pts each  
- Brick (8) – 28 pts each  
- Ore (5) – 34 pts each  

I’m obviously light on Brick, the single largest-value-per-unit resource. My first offer—3 Sheep for 1 Brick—was denied. The value question is whether 3 Sheep (39 pts) is actually “too much” for only one Brick (28 pts), so I’ll adjust to get the deal accepted while still increasing my total value.

After a quick re-price, 2 Sheep (26 pts) for 1 Brick (28 pts) gives me +2 points of value; I’d expect that to look fair to Player 0 yet still bump my own score.

[Offer: 2 Sheep -> 1 Brick]

rounds.response:
Player 1: I'd really like more brick—it's the most efficient way for me to boost my current value.  
I need 5 brick and can offer 25 sheep in total.  
[Offer: 25 Sheep -> 5 Brick]

rounds.response:
I can see every Brick I acquire is worth 28 to me, while each Sheep is only worth 13. Therefore any trade that converts more than 0.46 Sheep per Brick ( ≈ 13/28 ) benefits me. I’m currently asking ~5:1 (13/28 ≈ 0.46:1) and getting rejected, so Player 0 wants a premium. I’ll sweeten the offer slightly.  

[Offer: 4 Sheep -> 1 Brick]

rounds.response:
Current resource values (my side):
- Wheat: 18 x 5  = 90  
- Wood:  10 x 12 = 120  
- Sheep: 25 x 13 = 325  
- Brick:  8 x 28 = 224  
- Ore:    5 x 34 = 170  
Total value = 929

Brick is extremely valuable to me (28 per unit).  Player 0 has consistently declined 3-, 2-, and even 4-Sheep-for-1-Brick offers, and also turned down 25 Sheep for 5 Brick.  Since Sheep are my least efficient 13-value item and I have 25 in excess while Brick is scarce (only 8 units), the marginal value of Brick still dominates Sheep.

Next best way to extract value without giving up Brick or Ore is to leverage my Wheat (only valued 5 each).  I’ll now try to “sweeten” the deal to entice 1 Brick:

[Offer: 5 Wheat 3 Sheep -> 1 Brick]
